pageData.text: The mammalian eye is a complex and highly specialized sensory organ. The eye captures and focuses light, converting this stimulus into nerve impulses which are eventually interpreted as an image by the brain. In this investigation, you will be guided through the dissection and close examination of an adult mammalian eye.

pageData.title: Time Requirements
pageData.altText:
Preparation - 5 minutes
Activity 1: Eye dissection - 40 minutes

pageData.text:
When looking at an optical illusion, is it our eyes or our brain playing tricks on us? For centuries, philosophers and researchers have been trying to answer that question. Ancient Greek architects and artists often used optical illusions in their work. For example, their temple rooftops consist of straight lines at a slant yet appear as though they are curved. Plato, an ancient Greek philosopher, suggested that our eyes and brains work together to see the world.Today, neuroscientists use optical illusions to understand how the brain processes information from the eyes. It takes 10 milliseconds for the eye to “capture” an image. To save even more time, however, the brain makes assumptions about what it sees and tries to predict what is coming next. The brain and the eyes are in a constant loop of seeing and predicting.Click on the image shown here to observe an optical illusion. Does it look like it is moving? It is a static image, but it appears to be moving because of the way the brain interprets the contrasting borders and various sizes of the dots captured by the .Image attribution: Motion illusion in star arrangement by Fiestoforo, available under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported license at
https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Motion_illusion_in_star_arrangement.png

pageData.desc: A motion-based optical illusion in which circles of one color are arranged in a star pattern on a background of another color with small circles at the center getting progressively larger toward the outside. Each circle has a border made up of contrasting shading which gives the illusion that the circles are moving.
pageData.altText: A motion-based optical illusion in which circles of one color are arranged in a star pattern on a background of another color with small circles at the center getting progressively larger toward the outside. Each circle has a border made up of contrasting shading which gives the illusion that the circles are moving.

pageData.text: The states that each anatomical structure always reflects its function and vice versa. This concept becomes quite apparent when examining the mammalian eye. All specialized structures of the eye must work together with the nervous system in order for visual information to be perceived. In this investigation, a cow eye will be examined and dissected to delineate the relationship between structure (anatomy) and function (physiology).

pageData.subTitle: Eye Structure and Function
pageData.text: The eye is a key part of the visual apparatus that provides information about the size, shape, orientation, and location of objects in the environment. Light enters the eye through the transparent, window-like <button class='glossary-text'>cornea</button> and passes through a small opening in the pigmented <button class='glossary-text'>iris</button> called the <button class='glossary-text'>pupil</button>. Changes in the diameter of the pupil regulate the amount of light that enters the eye and passes through the <button class='glossary-text'>biconcave lens</button>. The <button class='glossary-text'>ciliary body</button>, located immediately posterior to the iris, is a muscular structure that is attached to the lens via <button class='glossary-text'>suspensory ligaments</button>. Contraction and relaxation of the ciliary body alter the shape of the lens, enabling near or distant focus. From the lens, light is projected onto the photosensitive <button class='glossary-text'>retina</button> at the back of the eye.

pageData.desc: Figure 1: A longitudinal cross section of a human eye with the cornea, iris, pupil, lens, coronary body, suspensory ligament, retina, and optic nerve labeled.
pageData.altText: Figure 1: A longitudinal cross section of a human eye with the cornea, iris, pupil, lens, coronary body, suspensory ligament, retina, and optic nerve labeled.

pageData.text: Interestingly, the projected image is inverted relative to the objects being viewed. The retina contains neurons that form the <button class='glossary-text'>optic nerve</button>, which conveys signals to the brain. The brain processes the visual information so that images are perceived “right side up.”

There are two common ways of describing the overall anatomy of the eye. First, the eye can be divided into anterior and posterior compartments, separated by the lens. The anterior compartment is filled with a watery fluid called the <button class='glossary-text'>aqueous humor</button>, and the posterior with a gelatinous fluid called the <button class='glossary-text'>vitreous humor</button>. (In the early days of Western medicine, body fluids were referred to as humors.) Both fluids contribute to maintaining the spherical shape of the eye. The aqueous humor is constantly produced by the ciliary body and circulates, providing lubrication for the iris, before being resorbed into the bloodstream. The vitreous humor is formed during development of the eye and is not replenished. The <button class='glossary-text'>hyaloid fossa</button> is an indentation in the anterior portion of the vitreous humor that helps hold the lens in place. Posteriorly, the vitreous humor serves to hold the retina in place.

pageData.question: Which of the following structures are found in the posterior compartment of the mammalian eye?

options.text: aqueous humor, lens, pupil, iris, cornea
pupil, lens, aqueous humor, vitreous humor

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: The anterior and posterior compartments of the eye are separated by the lens. The posterior compartment contains the vitreous humor and features the retina and optic nerve.

pageData.question: The anterior and posterior compartments of the eye are separated by which structure?

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: The lens is the structure that scientists have established as the boundary between the anterior and posterior compartments of the mammalian eye.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: One of the most common ways of describing the overall anatomy of the eye is to divide it into anterior and posterior halves, or compartments, with the lens as the dividing structure. The structures of the eye, along with these compartments, are shown here. The anterior compartment is filled with a watery fluid called the aqueous humor, and the posterior compartment with a gelatinous fluid called the vitreous humor. Both fluids help maintain the spherical shape of the eye.

img.alt: A longitudinal cross section of a human eye with the anterior and posterior compartments labeled.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: One of the most common ways of describing the overall anatomy of the eye is to divide it into anterior and posterior halves, or compartments, with the lens as the dividing structure. The structures of the eye, along with these compartments, are shown here. The anterior compartment is filled with a watery fluid called the aqueous humor, and the posterior compartment with a gelatinous fluid called the vitreous humor. Both fluids help maintain the spherical shape of the eye.

img.alt: A longitudinal cross section of a human eye with the anterior and posterior compartments labeled.

pageData.text: The eye can also be divided into three concentric layers, known as tunics: the outermost <button class='glossary-text'>fibrous tunic</button>, the middle <button class='glossary-text'>vascular tunic</button>, and the innermost <button class='glossary-text'>nervous tunic</button>. The <button class='glossary-text'>cornea</button> is the most anterior region of the fibrous tunic; the tough, opaque <button class='glossary-text'>sclera</button> forms the posterior part of the fibrous tunic, which protects the eye and helps maintain the shape of the eyeball. The vascular tunic, named for its role in supplying blood to the eye, consists of the <button class='glossary-text'>iris</button>, <button class='glossary-text'>ciliary body</button>, and <button class='glossary-text'>choroid</button>. A high concentration of dark pigment in the choroid reduces the scattering of light rays in the eye. The choroid of many animals, including cows, cats, and dogs (but not humans), has a reflective region known as the <button class='glossary-text'>tapetum lucidum</button>, which enhances night vision. The nervous tunic consists of the <button class='glossary-text'>retina</button> and contains the photoreceptor cells.

pageData.question: As part of your dissection of a cow eye, you will cut the eye into anterior and posterior halves using a scalpel and dissection scissors. As you do so, you will cut through the tunic layers of the eye. Which of the following describes the tunic layers in order from outermost to innermost?

options.text: fibrous tunic, vascular tunic, nervous tunic
nervous tunic, fibrous tunic, vascular tunic
vascular tunic, nervous tunic, fibrous tunic

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: The fibrous tunic is the outermost layer of the eye; the vascular tunic is the next layer down and the nervous tunic is the innermost layer.

pageData.question: Which of the following best describes the innermost tunic of the mammalian eye and its function?

options.text: vascular tunic; increases scattering of light
nervous tunic; relays signals to brain

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: The innermost tunic of the eye is the nervous tunic, which contains photoreceptor cells that perceive visual stimuli.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: Not only is the shape of the eye maintained by the fluids it contains, but also by the concentric tissue layers that surround it, known as tunics. The outermost fibrous tunic features the cornea at its most anterior region and the tough, opaque sclera at its posterior. The middle vascular tunic is named for its vascular network that supplies blood to the eye. The innermost nervous tunic contains the photoreceptor cells that allow the eye to perceive visual stimuli.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: Not only is the shape of the eye maintained by the fluids it contains, but also by the concentric tissue layers that surround it, known as tunics. The outermost fibrous tunic features the cornea at its most anterior region and the tough, opaque sclera at its posterior. The middle vascular tunic is named for its vascular network that supplies blood to the eye. The innermost nervous tunic contains the photoreceptor cells that allow the eye to perceive visual stimuli.

pageData.text: The is actually a multilayered array of neurons. The anterior layer—the first layer of neurons encountered by incoming rays of light—consists of ganglion cells, the axons of which converge at the to form the . Because there are no photoreceptors at the optic disc, it is often called the “blind spot.” Next, the light passes through additional layers of neurons, including the bipolar cells, which assist in the processing and transmission of visual information. Finally, the light strikes the photoreceptors, the rods and cones of the retina. Rods are sensitive to low levels of light, but are not sensitive to color. Cones function best in bright light. Because different types of cones are responsive to different wavelengths of light, cones enable color vision. The is the anterior boundary of the photoreceptor-containing portion of the retina. From the ora serrata, the retina extends anteriorly to the .

pageData.question: There are optical illusions you can perform that will allow you to identify your blind spot, a portion of your field of view where objects cannot be perceived. Which of the following best explains this blind spot phenomenon?

options.text: The portion of the retina taken up by the optic nerve does not have photoreceptors.
The retinal neurons that form the optic disc are covered up by the choroid.
The optic nerve is covered by rods and not cones.
A portion of the retina is covered by both rods and cones, whose functions cancel out.
The blind spot phenomenon is an illusion only.

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: The retina is covered in photoreceptors except where retinal neurons converge at the optic disc to form the optic nerve.

pageData.question: Which of the following is most directly involved in the eye’s perception of color?

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: There are two different types of photoreceptors in the retina. Cones are photoreceptors that function best in bright light conditions and are sensitive to different colors of light. Rods are photoreceptors that function best in low levels of light but they are not sensitive to color.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: The retina is covered with neurons. When light passes into the eye and hits the retina, the first layer of neurons it encounters is made up of ganglion cells, the axons of which converge at the optic disc to form the optic nerve. The second layer of neurons the light passes through includes bipolar cells, which facilitate the processing and transmission of visual information. The final layer the light encounters is made up of photoreceptors called rods and cones, however these receptors are not present at the site of the optic nerve. The rods function best at night, or in other low-light conditions, but they are not sensitive to color; cones function best during the day, or in bright light conditions, and are sensitive to different colors of light.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: The retina is covered with neurons. When light passes into the eye and hits the retina, the first layer of neurons it encounters is made up of ganglion cells, the axons of which converge at the optic disc to form the optic nerve. The second layer of neurons the light passes through includes bipolar cells, which facilitate the processing and transmission of visual information. The final layer the light encounters is made up of photoreceptors called rods and cones, however these receptors are not present at the site of the optic nerve. The rods function best at night, or in other low-light conditions, but they are not sensitive to color; cones function best during the day, or in bright light conditions, and are sensitive to different colors of light.

This investigation requires safety goggles, disposable gloves, and a lab apron.

pageData.text: Follow the instructions for this activity closely and observe established laboratory safety practices, including appropriate personal protective equipment (PPE); safety glasses or goggles, gloves, and lab aprons must be worn when dissecting. Do not eat, drink, or chew gum while performing the dissection. Use proper hygiene practices before, during, and after the lab, including washing your hands before and after performing the dissection. Review pertinent portions of any Safety Data Sheets (SDS) before beginning the activity. Keep pets and children away from lab materials and equipment.
Dissections require special attention to safety. Please follow these additional precautions:

text: Clean the counter or workspace thoroughly before and after the dissection, using isopropyl alcohol (or other non-bleach disinfectant).

pageData.text: Isopropyl alcohol (rubbing alcohol) is flammable. Keep away from open flame if using alcohol as disinfectant.

text: Wash your hands thoroughly with soap and water before and after the dissection.
Only perform the dissection on the dissecting tray. This will contain both the specimen and any excess fluids.
Spread the absorbent pad blue side down underneath the tray to capture any spilled fluid.
In general, scissors are used more frequently than the scalpel, especially when care must be taken not to cut too deeply into the specimen.
Scalpels are used infrequently in most dissection labs and require special handling and disposal:

pageData.text: View the following video: Using a Scalpel

text: Never cut toward your holding hand and fingers.
Cut in a downward motion using a steady, even pressure.
Always use a sharp blade.
Do not use a scalpel that is nicked, bent, or damaged.
Do not use a scalpel to cut through bone or heavy cartilage.
Never use a scalpel for anything other than dissection.

pageData.subTitle: Carolina’s Perfect Solution®
pageData.text: Independent, certified laboratory analyses of specimens fixed in Carolina’s Perfect Solution® have found that it is nontoxic and does not give off dangerous fumes. This means that, for safety purposes, use of Carolina’s Perfect Solution® specimens does not require specialized ventilation. Carolina does recommend performing the dissection in a well-ventilated room with some active ventilation when working with any preserved specimens. For a home setting, this may include opening windows and turning on a ceiling fan. The safe nature of Carolina’s Perfect Solution® also means that in most localities there are no mandated disposal requirements.
Carolina’s Perfect Solution® causes mild skin irritation if suitable PPE is not worn. Avoid contact with skin and eyes. Do not ingest specimen, especially if you are or may become pregnant.

pageData.subTitle: Storage of Specimens
pageData.text: If it is necessary to store the specimen between work periods, you may choose to place it in the plastic storage bag with as much of the original solution as possible. Establishing an airtight seal is the best way to retain specimen integrity and prevent drying out of the specimen. First, squeeze as much air out of the specimen bag as possible before securing the opening with a rubber band, tape, or a binder clip. After closing the bag, the specimen can be stored in a larger, airtight box or bag at room temperature.

pageData.title: Pre-Lab Assessment Introduction
pageData.text: Directions: Complete this pre-lab assessment to continue to the rest of the investigation. You will need a score of 100% to pass the assessment. This assessment can be attempted as many times as necessary to achieve a passing score. You may return to the pre-lab sections to study before each attempt.For each question, select your response and then click Submit to see how you did. Click Next to continue to the next question. A final results page will appear upon completion of this assessment with your overall performance.

assestmentData.question: As you dissect your mammalian eye specimen, which of the following structures could you reasonably expect to detach from the specimen as you cut it in half along the frontal plane?
Which of the following structures in the posterior compartment of your mammalian eye specimen will be visible during the investigation, but would not be present if you were dissecting a human eye?
Which of the following best describes the path of light from the environment to the retina in the mammalian eye?
Which of the following scenarios describes inappropriate handling of a scalpel?

options.text: Marc uses only the scalpel to cut through thick or tough tissues.
Tony disposes of his scalpel upon noticing the blade has dulled.
Luca uses the scalpel to make a small incision, then scissors to enlarge it.
Walter keeps the scalpel blade sheathed when it is not in use.
Aaron uses steady pressure as he makes an incision with the scalpel.

assestmentData.question: Which of the following best describes a proper workstation set-up for this investigation?

pageData.title: Pre-Lab Assessment Result

You have unlimited attempts to pass this assessment. Click the Review Pre-Lab button to be returned to the start of the pre-lab section.
Review the dissection instructions (while referring to the dissection mat) and the glossary at the end of this investigation.
Print out the dissection procedure to avoid getting fluid from the specimen on your computer or mobile device.
Clean the work area.
Put on your PPE: safety glasses, gloves, and lab apron, and keep them on during dissection and cleanup.
Lay the pad on the work area with the white, absorbent side facing up.
Lay out all dissecting instruments on the pad.
Place the dissecting tray in the middle of the pad to absorb any fluid that might spill onto the work area.
Position the dissection mat so it is easy to read. In the Eye Dissection Activity, structures that are shown on the dissection mat are indicated by numbers in parentheses.

Use the anatomical directions and planes in Table 1 to help you orient the preserved eye specimen in this investigation. You will start Activity 1 by removing the excess superficial fatty tissue surrounding the specimen, then examining its external structures. To examine the interior structures, you will divide the specimen into anterior and posterior halves.

tableData.text: Above, over; synonymous with dorsal in brain dissection, especially for a quadruped
Below, under; synonymous with ventral in brain dissection, especially for a quadruped
Away from the midline; to the side
A significant distance below the surface
Divides the body into longitudinal left and right portions
Divides the body into equal left and right halves
Perpendicular to the long axis; produces cross sections
Divides the body into dorsal and ventral portions

typeBefore.text: Click to view a video showing major features of the eye.

pageData.text: Use scissors and forceps to carefully remove excess superficial fatty tissue from the outside of the eye. Use the photos from the upper left-hand area of the front of the dissection mat for reference. The photo on the left indicates an eye that is still covered in fatty tissue, and the photo on the right shows an eye with the fatty tissue removed.

Using the dissection mat as a guide, locate the nerve (9), the opaque <button class='glossary-text'>sclera</button> (13), and the transparent <button class='glossary-text'>cornea</button> (5). You may wish to photograph these structures before proceeding. In the following steps you are asked to identify and photograph a number of structures. Each photograph may have multiple structures displayed. Take notes to keep track of which structures are presented in each picture.

Carefully slice the fibrous outer tunic of the eye in half along its anterior-posterior axis, as shown on the front upper right area of the dissection mat. Do not cut deeply into the eye or squeeze it too tightly, so as not to damage the interior structures. You may begin the cut with a scalpel and finish with small scissors, or you may use a scalpel for the entire cut. The watery fluid that comes out as you make the incision is the <button class='glossary-text'>aqueous humor</button> (1). If some of the <button class='glossary-text'>vitreous humor</button> (15) begins to come out of the eye as you cut through the sclera, let it come out slowly. As you cut, notice how tough the protective sclera is.

Note: If you wish, pat the lens dry on the absorbent pad, then allow the lens to dry more overnight. Place it over a piece of paper with text printed on it, such as a newspaper. You should be able to observe the magnifying ability of the lens.

Examine the anterior half of the eye; locate and identify the lens (8). Gently remove the lens and squeeze it between your fingers. Notice that, unlike a camera lens, the lens of the eye is relatively soft.

Orient the anterior half of the eye so that the cut portion is in contact with the tray and the cornea is facing up. Gently cut out the cornea at the point where it meets the sclera, as shown on the back of the dissection mat. Compare the transparent cornea to the opaque sclera that surrounds it. Cut the cornea in half to observe its thickness, then set it aside.

The darkly-pigmented ring that is revealed when the cornea is removed is the <button class='glossary-text'>iris</button> (7). Just posterior to the iris is the <button class='glossary-text'>ciliary body</button> (4), which connects the iris with the serrated tissue disk known as the <button class='glossary-text'>ora serrata</button> (10).

Use forceps to gently remove the iris and ora serrata as indicated on the back of the dissection mat, and examine these structures closely before setting them aside. If the vitreous humor remains in the eye, gently slip it out and set it aside as well. Try to locate the <button class='glossary-text'>hyaloid fossa</button> (6), the indentation in the central anterior region of the vitreous humor. Surrounding the hyaloid fossa are the <button class='glossary-text'>suspensory ligaments</button> (14) that suspend the lens and0 stretch it to focus. You may also notice dark lines around the hyaloid fossa. These lines contain pigment from the iris.

Examine the posterior half of the eye. Identify the <button class='glossary-text'>retina</button> (12), which contains the photoreceptor cells. Locate the <button class='glossary-text'>optic disc</button>, or “blind spot” (2), which is the beginning of the <button class='glossary-text'>optic nerve</button>. Notice the darkly pigmented <button class='glossary-text'>choroid</button> (3). The shiny, iridescent portion of the choroid is the <button class='glossary-text'>tapetum lucidum</button>.

text: Dispose of any excess fluids down the drain with the water running. Allow the faucet to run for about 30 seconds to dilute the fluids.
Place the specimen in its storage bag and seal tightly. If you are finished working with your specimen, put the bag into an opaque trash bag for disposal in the household garbage.
Rinse and carefully air dry the dissection tools, and return the materials to your equipment kit.

Sanitize the workspace with isopropyl alcohol (or other non-bleach disinfectant) and paper towels. If this is insufficient for removing grease during cleanup, use soap and water, followed by more alcohol/disinfectant.

This map describes the procedural workflow for this investigation.
You will start by setting up the work area and dissection the tools.
In Activity 1, you will need to remove the excess superficial fatty tissue of specimen. Next, locate and identify external structures of intact specimen. Then, divide the specimen into anterior and posterior halves. You then need to locate and identify structures of anterior half. You will need to locate and identify the structures of posterior half.

tableData.text: Above, over; synonymous with dorsal in brain dissection, especially for a quadruped
Below, under; synonymous with ventral in brain dissection, especially for a quadruped
Away from the midline; to the side
A significant distance below the surface

data.title: Aqueous humor
data.content: Anterior compartment is filled with a watery fluid, contribute to maintaining the spherical shape of the eye

data.title: Biconcave lens
data.content: Refracts (bends) light rays so that they are focused

data.title: Choroid
data.content: The pigmented vascular layer of the eye

data.title: Ciliary body
data.content: Located immediately posterior to the iris, is a muscular structure that is attached to the lens

data.title: Cornea
data.content: Transparent part of the coat of the eyeball that covers the iris and pupil

data.title: Fibrous tunic
data.content: One of three eye concentric layers, the outermost layer

data.title: Hyaloid fossa
data.content: An indentation in the anterior portion of the vitreous humor that helps hold the lens in place

data.title: Iris
data.content: The colored part of the eye

data.title: Nervous tunic
data.content: One of three eye concentric layers, the inner layer

data.title: Optic disc
data.content: A small area at the rear of the eyeball where rods and cones contact other nerve cells in the retina, “blind spot”

data.title: Optic nerve
data.content: Convergence of nerve fibers in the optic disk gives rise to the optic nerve, which leads to the brain

data.title: Ora serrata
data.content: The anterior boundary of the photoreceptor-containing portion of the retina

data.title: Principle of complementarity of structure and function
data.content: Each anatomical structure always reflects its function and vice versa

data.title: Pupil
data.content: Round opening in the center of the iris

data.title: Retina
data.content: Photoreceptive system in the back of the eye

data.title: Sclera
data.content: Forms the posterior part of the fibrous tunic, which protects the eye and helps maintain the shape of the eyeball

data.title: Suspensory ligaments
data.content: Attaches the ciliary body  to the lens

data.title: Tapetum lucidum
data.content: Found in the choroid of many animals (cows, cats, and dogs, but not humans) a reflective region that enhances night vision

data.title: Vascular tunic
data.content: One of three eye concentric layers, the middle layer

data.title: Vitreous humor
data.content: Eye, the posterior with a gelatinous fluid, contribute to maintaining the spherical shape of the eye
